title: Famous Feuds
description: Historic rivalries and feuds between people and families

questions.question: The Hatfields and McCoys are perhaps America's most famous feuding families. In which U.S. states did they live?
questions.explanation: The Hatfield-McCoy feud took place along the Tug Fork of the Big Sandy River, which forms the border between West Virginia (Hatfields) and Kentucky (McCoys). The feud lasted from about 1863 to 1891.

questions.question: Which two powerful Italian families had a famous rivalry that inspired Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet'?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet' features the feuding Montague and Capulet families of Verona. While these are fictional names, the story may have been inspired by real medieval Italian family conflicts.

questions.question: The brothers who founded Adidas and Puma had a famous feud. What was their surname?
questions.explanation: Adolf (Adi) and Rudolf Dassler were brothers who ran a shoe company together in Germany. After a bitter falling out during WWII, Adi founded Adidas and Rudolf founded Puma, both headquartered in the same town of Herzogenaurach.

questions.question: Which two famous American politicians had a bitter rivalry that culminated in a deadly duel in 1804?
questions.explanation: Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr's political rivalry ended in a duel on July 11, 1804, at Weehawken, New Jersey. Burr fatally shot Hamilton, who died the next day.

questions.question: The Wars of the Roses was a feudal conflict between which two English royal houses?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses (1455-1487) was a series of civil wars between the House of Lancaster (red rose) and the House of York (white rose) for control of the English throne.

questions.question: Which two famous composers had a well-known rivalry in 18th-century Vienna?
questions.explanation: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Antonio Salieri were contemporaries in Vienna whose rivalry became legendary, though it was greatly dramatized in the play and film 'Amadeus.' Their actual relationship was more nuanced than pure rivalry.

questions.question: Which famous American newspaper magnates engaged in a ruthless circulation war known as 'Yellow Journalism'?
options: Horace Greeley and James Gordon Bennett
William Randolph Hearst and Joseph Pulitzer
questions.explanation: William Randolph Hearst (New York Journal) and Joseph Pulitzer (New York World) waged a fierce circulation war in the 1890s. Their sensationalized reporting became known as 'Yellow Journalism' and helped push the U.S. into the Spanish-American War.

questions.question: The Guelphs and Ghibellines were rival factions in which country during the Middle Ages?
questions.explanation: The Guelphs (supporting the Pope) and Ghibellines (supporting the Holy Roman Emperor) were rival factions in medieval Italy. Their conflict shaped Italian politics for centuries and features prominently in Dante's works.

questions.question: Which two tech company founders had a famous decades-long rivalry in the personal computer industry?
questions.explanation: Steve Jobs (Apple) and Bill Gates (Microsoft) had a legendary rivalry spanning decades. Despite their competitive tension over operating systems and personal computing, they maintained a complex relationship of both rivalry and respect.

questions.question: Which two famous boxing rivals fought three times, including the 'Thrilla in Manila'?
options: Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Durán
questions.explanation: Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier fought three epic bouts between 1971 and 1975. Their rivalry defined heavyweight boxing, culminating in the 'Thrilla in Manila' in 1975, often called the greatest fight ever.

questions.question: The feud between Queen Elizabeth I of England and Mary, Queen of Scots, ended with what outcome?
questions.explanation: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had a claim to the English throne, was held prisoner by Elizabeth I for 19 years before being convicted of plotting against Elizabeth and executed in 1587.

questions.question: Which two famous rappers had an East Coast-West Coast feud in the 1990s?
options: Tupac Shakur and The Notorious B.I.G.
questions.explanation: Tupac Shakur (West Coast) and The Notorious B.I.G. (Biggie Smalls, East Coast) were at the center of a rap feud in the mid-1990s. Both were tragically killed in separate drive-by shootings in 1996 and 1997.

questions.question: What long-running political feud existed between U.S. Presidents John Adams and Thomas Jefferson?
options: They had opposing visions for the new nation's government
They competed for the same woman
questions.explanation: Adams (Federalist) favored a strong central government while Jefferson (Democratic-Republican) championed states' rights. Their feud lasted years, but remarkably, they reconciled in old age and both died on July 4, 1826.

questions.question: Which famous literary feud saw Mark Twain openly criticize which other American author's writing?
questions.explanation: Mark Twain wrote a scathing essay called 'Fenimore Cooper's Literary Offences' (1895) criticizing James Fenimore Cooper's 'The Deerslayer' and 'The Last of the Mohicans' for literary violations and inaccuracies.

questions.question: The Campbell and MacDonald clans in Scotland had a centuries-long feud. What infamous 1692 event marked its darkest chapter?
questions.explanation: The Massacre of Glencoe on February 13, 1692, saw government soldiers (many of them Campbells) kill 38 members of the MacDonald clan while being hosted as guests. It remains one of the most notorious events in Scottish history.
